msDesc.head: A Proverbs, legal texts, etc., in Latin and Anglo-Norman; England, late 12th century. B Assize of Clarendon, Inquest of sheriffs, Magna Carta; England, early 13th century. C Instituta Knuti, Coronation Charter of Henry I, etc. England, late 12th century.

supportDesc.collation: 1(8) (fols. 1-8), 2(8+2?) (fols. 9-18, with fols. 17-18, possibly a bifolium, added after 8?) | 3(8+1?) (fols. 19-27, with fol. 27 added after 8?; or fol. 27 may belong with quire 4), 4(2) (fols. 28-9) | 5(8)-6(8) (fols. 30-45). Uncertain in places due to 19th-century repairs.

binding.p: 17th- or 18th- century calf over pasteboards, extensively repaired in the 19th century. Pricks marking out the medieval sewing stations are visible, especially in parts A and C.

history.provenance: Apparently made up from three independent units (A fols. 1-18, B fols. 19-27, C fols. 30-45), perhaps only combined in the 16th century when the legal contents of all three parts were heavily annotated by a single hand. Unit C, fols. 30-45, was apparently in the fifteenth century part of a larger legal manuscript; see further item 12 below. Parts A and C may however have shared a common earlier provenance based on similarities of script and decoration and prickings for binding.
The annotator collated the text of item 2 against 'Mr Lucas boke' and quoted 'Fabian' as an authority (fol. 30r).
Richard Rawlinson, 1690–1755; his source of acquisition not known.

recordHist.source: Description by Matthew Holford (March 2024). Previously described in the Quarto Catalogue (W. D. Macray, Catalogi codicum manuscriptorum Bibliothecæ Bodleianæ...viri munificentissimi Ricardi Rawlinson, J.C.D., codicum...complectens, Quarto Catalogues V, 5 fascicles, 1862–1900). Quarto Catalogue, cols. 329–30 Summary Catalogue, vol. 3, p. 217

ref.title: JONAS: Répertoire des textes et des manuscrits médiévaux d'oc et d'oïl
The Production and Use of English Manuscripts 1060 to 1220

listBibl.bibl: Maria Careri et al., Livres et écritures en français et en occitan au XIIe siècle: catalogue illustré, Scritture e libri del medioevo 8 (Roma: Viella, 2011), cat. 64.
Bruce R. O’Brien, God’s Peace and King’s Peace: the Laws of Edward the Confessor (Philadelphia, 1999)
N. R. Ker, Catalogue of Manuscripts Containing Anglo-Saxon. [Reissued with supplement]. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1990, no. 348

msItem.title: Short florilegium
msItem.note: Sentences and questions associated with the school of Anselm of Laon (i-ii, v), two short extracts from Augustine (iii-iv), and maxims (vi-vii). The sources and circulation of vi-vii are discussed by Michael Reeve, 'The Florilegium Angelicum and ‘Seneca’, De moribus', in Et Amicorum: Essays on Renaissance Humanism and Philosophy (2018), 262-80; additionally iv-vi circulate together in Cambridge, Trinity College, MS. B. 1. 30.

msItem.incipit: Deus fecit hominem bonum et iustum hac conditione tamen quod si frangeret obedientiam, morte moreretur
msItem.explicit: quia iustum et immunem a peccato inuaserat
msItem.note: Anselmi Laudunensis et Radulfi fratri ejus sententias excerptas, ed. G. Lefèvre (1895), pp. 13-17, here ending differently (cf. D. O. Lottin, 'Pour une édition critique du «Liber Pancrisis»', Recherches de théologie ancienne et médiévale, 13 (1946), 185-201, no. 147)

msItem.incipit: Queritur cum ubique totus deus esset quomodo magis potest fuit in utero uirginis
msItem.note: Cf. PL 153.303 and D. O. Lottin, 'Nouveaux fragments théologiques de l'école d'Anselme de Laon: Manuscrits de Munich', Recherches de théologie ancienne et médiévale, 13 (1946), 202-221, no. 292

msItem.incipit: Queritur an Christus ex eo quod uerbum est posuerit animam, an ex eo quod humana anima est, an ex eo quod caro est
Laudari a male uiuentibus nolo, abhorreo, detestor
msItem.note: Short extract from Augustine, Serm. Frangipane 2 (PL 46.961).

msItem.incipit: Cum homo mutatur de uiciis ad seruitium dei

listBibl.bibl: Cédric Giraud, 'Théologie et Pédagogie au XIIe siècle : les sentences d'Anselme de Laon et de son école dans le manuscrit Paris, BNF, n.a.l. 181', Archives d'histoire doctrinale et littéraire du Moyen Âge 79 (2012) 193-287, no. 129 = D. O. Lottin, 'Nouveaux fragments théologiques de l'école d'Anselme de Laon: Deux manuscrits d'Oxford', Recherches de théologie ancienne et médiévale, 14 (1947), 5-31, no. 416

msItem.incipit: Fugienda sunt omnibus modis et abscidenda igni ac ferro
msItem.explicit: que sola homines proximos deo facit

msItem.incipit: Staterum ne transileas id est ne pretergrediaris iusticiam

msItem.title: Leges Edwardi Confessoris
msItem.incipit: Post quartum annum adquisitionis regis Willelmi istius terre

listBibl.bibl: Early English Laws, ECf2, sigl. Rl
Bruce R. O’Brien, God’s Peace and King’s Peace: the Laws of Edward the Confessor (Philadelphia, 1999)
Felix Liebermann, ed., Die Gesetze der Angelsachsen, 3 vols (Halle, 1903–1916), vol. 1, pp. 627–70

msItem.author: Guernes de Pont-ste-Maxence
msItem.title: La vie de saint Thomas le martyr
msItem.note: (extracts, mostly relating to the Constitutions of Clarendon)
msItem.incipit: Si uus uulez les leis le rei Henri oir
msItem.explicit: I a ni aura un denier de ma terre dime.

msItem.title: Proverbs
msItem.note: Some attributed to Serlo of Wilton.
msItem.incipit:
Deez ait tant maistres, dist le crapolt a la herce.
Sic buffo crati, Ve cui sunt dominati.
Buffo crate fatur, Ve turba quibus dominatur
msItem.explicit:
De pute espine, pute furdine.
Meuz valt turn de mulin ke pet de mastin.
msItem.note: Ker notes two Middle English proverbs on fol. 13v.

listBibl.bibl: Edmund Stengel, ‘Die beiden Sammlungen altfranzösischer Sprichwörter in der Oxforder Hs. Rawlinson C.641’, Zeitschrift für französische Sprache und Literatur 21 (1899), 1-21 at 3-7 (this manuscript)
Albert C. Friend, ‘The Proverbs of Serlo of Wilton’, Mediaeval Studies 16 (1954), 179-218 (beginning with his proverb 7)

msItem.title: Proverbs ('Li Proverbe que dit li vilains')
msItem.incipit:
Ci sunt li proverbe que dit li vilains.
Qui de tote se guard de alcune estape.
Qui od conseil oure ne fait ablasmer.
Asez set chat ki barbes il leche.
msItem.explicit:
Qui riens na rien ne pert ne ses amis nel plaignent.
Fol marchant folement bargaigne.

listBibl.bibl: Edmund Stengel, ‘Die beiden Sammlungen altfranzösischer Sprichwörter in der Oxforder Hs. Rawlinson C.641’, Zeitschrift für französische Sprache und Literatur 21 (1899), 1-21 at 7-13 (this manuscript)

layoutDesc.layout: 31 lines. Ruled in leadpoint, ruled space 140 92-5 (inner bounding lines). In one column except for fols. 13v-15r, two columns.

decoDesc.decoNote: (fols. 1r-4r) plain initials with minor arabesque decoration in the ink of the text
(fols. 10r-13r) plain coloured initials alternating green and red.

msItem.title: Assize of Clarendon
msItem.rubric: Incipit Asisa de Clarenduna, facta a Rege Henrico, scil. secundo, de assensu archiepiscoporum, episcoporum, abbatum, comitum, baronum totius Anglie

listBibl.bibl: William Stubbs, ed., Select Charters and Other Illustrations of English Constitutional History, 9th edn, rev. by H. W. C. Davis (Oxford, 1921), pp. 170–3, from this manuscript.
William Stubbs, ed., Select Charters and Other Illustrations of English Constitutional History, 9th edn, rev. by H. W. C. Davis (Oxford, 1921), pp. 175–78, from this manuscript.

msItem.title: Magna Carta (1215)
msItem.note: An addition, written slightly later than the preceding item.

The text (and later annotations) are discussed by David Carpenter, 'Magna Carta 1215', The Magna Carta Project: The Copies of Magna Carta, raising the possibility 'that the copy derives from an unofficial text of the Charter made on 16 June'
Rest of fol. 29r and fol. 29v blank.

layoutDesc.layout: 29 long lines, written above top line. Two series of prickings in the outer margins, and pricking in the inner margins. Ruled space 130-5 90-5 (inner bounding lines)

decoDesc.decoNote: Plain coloured initials alternating light blue and red.

msItem.title: 'Instituta Cnuti'
msItem.note: One of the Latin translations of Cnut's code (I-II Cnut). There are six Old English glosses (fols. 32r, 33r, 34v, 40v: see Ker) also found in the Textus Roffensis but not in other copies.

listBibl.bibl: F. Liebermann, 'On the Instituta Cnuti Aliorumque Regum Anglorum', Transactions of the Royal Historical Society, New Series, Vol. 7 (1893), pp. 77-107
Felix Liebermann, ed., Die Gesetze der Angelsachsen, 3 vols (Halle, 1903–1916), vol. 1, pp. 612-616

msItem.title: Coronation Charter of Henry I

rubric.add: Instituciones Henrici regis anno domini Mo Cm. primo

msItem.note: So-called 'Rochester' version, i.e. that found in the Textus Roffensis.

msItem.title: Articles of William I
msItem.incipit: In primis quod super omnia unum uellet deum

listBibl.bibl: Felix Liebermann, ed., Die Gesetze der Angelsachsen, 3 vols (Halle, 1903–1916), vol. 1, pp. 486–88.

msItem.note: 14th-century table of contents: In isto libro continentur infrascripta .1. Excerpta de legibus sinodis et conciliis paparum et aliorum in principio .2. Instituciones Knuti regis Angl' ante conquestum .3. Instituciones Henrici regis anno domini Mo Cmo primo in Latinam .4. Leges Willelmi conquestoris .5. Tractatus Henrici regis secundi de legibus et consuetudinibus Anglie compositus per ranulphum Glanvillam .6. Assisa de Clarendon facta a rege Henrico secundo .7. Carta de Rovndmeide facto anno regni regis Johannis 17mo.. Items 4-6 are later (late 14th- / early 15th-century) additions. Item 7 and the addition to item 5 are added by a 16th-century annotator (discussed above). Contrary to earlier commentators, only items 2-3 can be identified with certainty in the present manuscript; the rubrics on fols. 31r and 43r are in the same hand as the table of contents, a hand not found elsewhere in the manuscript.

layoutDesc.layout: 31 long lines; ruled in leadpoint; written above top line; ruled space c. 140 90 .

handDesc.handNote: Two hands: fols. 30r-35v; fols. 35v-45r, the second resembling that of fols. 12v-13r.

decoDesc.decoNote: 1- and 2-line initials, alternating green and red, occasionally with arabesque decoration in the contrasting colour.

history.provenance: Texts closely related to those found in the Textus Roffensis, perhaps suggesting an origin in Kent.
